nodes.messageHeadline: fix: prevent '.' shortcut when modifier keys are pressed (#86)

nodes.body:
Modify the '.' key handler to only execute moveToCenterOfViewport when no modifier keys (ctrl, alt, shift, meta) are pressed. This prevents interference with other keyboard shortcuts that use '.' in combination with modifier keys.

`<Ctrl-.>` に設定しているブラウザのショートカットキー､その他拡張のショートカットキーが反応しなくなるので
ctrl, alt, shift, meta キーを押している場合は `moveToCenterOfViewport` が実行されないようにしました｡

nodes.messageHeadline: feat: replace uuid package to crypto.randomUUID (#82)

nodes.body:
Since the uuid package is only used to generate uuid v4, I replaced it with [crypto.randomUUID()](https://nodejs.org/api/crypto.html#cryptorandomuuidoptions) .  
This reduces the number of packages that need to be maintained.

fix: Fix syntax highlighting disappearing on hover by passing filenam…

nodes.body:
## Summary
- Fix syntax highlighting that disappears when hovering over files, especially with large diffs
- Pass filename as a prop through the component hierarchy instead of relying on the global currentFilename variable
- Remove the global currentFilename variable completely as it was causing issues

## Problem
When hovering over diff lines, all lines were using the same global `currentFilename` variable for language detection, causing incorrect syntax highlighting. The global variable approach was fundamentally flawed as it couldn't handle multiple files being rendered simultaneously.

## Solution
- Added `filename` prop to `PrismSyntaxHighlighter`, `EnhancedPrismSyntaxHighlighter`, `DiffLineRow`, `DiffChunk`, and `SideBySideDiffChunk`
- Pass the actual filename from `DiffViewer` through the component hierarchy
- Each component now receives the correct filename for proper language detection
- Removed the global `currentFilename` variable and `setCurrentFilename` function entirely

## Why global variables were problematic
Using a global variable for filename was a mistake because:
- Multiple files can be rendered at the same time in the diff view
- React components can re-render in any order
- The global state could be overwritten by any component, causing all components to use the wrong filename

## Test plan
- [x] Tested locally with large diffs
- [x] Verified syntax highlighting remains stable when hovering
- [x] All tests pass

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

  • Added filename prop to PrismSyntaxHighlighter, EnhancedPrismSyntaxHighlighter, DiffLineRow, DiffChunk, and SideBySideDiffChunk
  • Pass the actual filename from DiffViewer through the component hierarchy
  • Each component now receives the correct filename for proper language detection
  • Removed the global currentFilename variable and setCurrentFilename function entirely

Why global variables were problematic

Using a global variable for filename was a mistake because:

  • Multiple files can be rendered at the same time in the diff view
  • React components can re-render in any order
  • The global state could be overwritten by any component, causing all components to use the wrong filename

Test plan

  • Tested locally with large diffs
  • Verified syntax highlighting remains stable when hovering
  • All tests pass

🤖 Generated with Claude Code

nodes.messageHeadline: perf: Improve keyboard navigation performance with React.memo (#72)

nodes.body:
## Summary

This PR optimizes the performance of keyboard navigation in large diffs by preventing unnecessary re-renders of syntax highlighter components.

## Changes

### Performance Optimizations
- Added React.memo to `PrismSyntaxHighlighter` and `EnhancedPrismSyntaxHighlighter` components
- Used useCallback for render functions to ensure proper memoization
- Result: **81.7% reduction** in keyboard navigation latency (474ms → 87ms)

### Performance Measurement Infrastructure
- Created performance measurement scripts for consistent testing
- Added comparison tool to track performance changes between commits
- Improved measurement timing accuracy to properly capture React rendering

### CI/CD Improvements
- Added GitHub Actions workflow for automated performance testing on PRs
- Tests compare base vs head branch performance
- Fails PR if performance degrades by >10%
- Shows results in Job Summary and PR comments

## Performance Results

| Metric | Before | After | Improvement |
|--------|--------|-------|-------------|
| Average Navigation Time | 474.05ms | 86.67ms | 81.7% faster |

The optimization is particularly effective for large diffs with many syntax highlighted code blocks.

## Test Plan
- [x] Run performance tests locally with `pnpm perf`
- [x] Compare results with `pnpm perf:compare`
- [x] Verify no visual or functional changes
- [x] Test GitHub Actions workflow on this PR

nodes.messageHeadline: feat: Enable watch mode for dot argument with comparison (#73)

nodes.body:
## Summary
- Allow watch mode to work when using '.' as the first argument even when comparing with another branch (e.g., 'difit . origin/main')
- Previously, this would be treated as a specific commit comparison and disable watching
- Added unit test to verify the behavior

## Test plan
- [x] Run `difit . origin/main` and verify that file watching is enabled
- [x] Modify a file and verify that the diff automatically reloads
- [x] Run existing tests with `npm test` to ensure no regression
- [x] Run `difit commit1 commit2` and verify watch mode is still disabled for specific commits

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

nodes.body: ## Summary - Add a new comment list view (Shift+L) that shows all comments in a modal with keyboard navigation - Implement scope-based keyboard navigation management using react-hotkeys-hook - Make Shift+C and Shift+D shortcuts available globally, even when modals are open ## Changes ### Comment List View - New `CommentsListModal` component that displays all comments in a scrollable list - Full keyboard navigation support (j/k for navigation, Enter to jump, d to delete) - Accessible from CommentsDropdown or via Shift+L shortcut - Preserves the same comment UI design as inline comments ### Keyboard Navigation Improvements - Migrated from custom keyboard handling to react-hotkeys-hook library - Implemented scope-based shortcut management ('navigation' and 'comments-list' scopes) - Moved HotkeysProvider to root level for proper scope management - Added Shift+D shortcut for deleting all comments - Made Shift+C (copy all) and Shift+D (delete all) available in both navigation and modal contexts ### Code Organization - Refactored navigation utilities into separate modules for better maintainability - Updated all modals to properly manage keyboard scopes - Added comprehensive tests for the new features ## Test plan - [x] Open comment list with Shift+L - [x] Navigate comments with j/k or arrow keys - [x] Jump to comment location with Enter - [x] Delete individual comments with d key - [x] Use Shift+C and Shift+D in both main view and modal - [x] Verify other shortcuts are disabled when modals are open - [x] Close modal with Escape - [x] All existing tests pass - [x] New tests added for CommentsListModal and scope management 🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)
nodes.bodyHTML:
Summary

  • Add a new comment list view (Shift+L) that shows all comments in a modal with keyboard navigation
  • Implement scope-based keyboard navigation management using react-hotkeys-hook
  • Make Shift+C and Shift+D shortcuts available globally, even when modals are open

Changes

Comment List View

  • New CommentsListModal component that displays all comments in a scrollable list
  • Full keyboard navigation support (j/k for navigation, Enter to jump, d to delete)
  • Accessible from CommentsDropdown or via Shift+L shortcut
  • Preserves the same comment UI design as inline comments

Keyboard Navigation Improvements

  • Migrated from custom keyboard handling to react-hotkeys-hook library
  • Implemented scope-based shortcut management ('navigation' and 'comments-list' scopes)
  • Moved HotkeysProvider to root level for proper scope management
  • Added Shift+D shortcut for deleting all comments
  • Made Shift+C (copy all) and Shift+D (delete all) available in both navigation and modal contexts

Code Organization

  • Refactored navigation utilities into separate modules for better maintainability
  • Updated all modals to properly manage keyboard scopes
  • Added comprehensive tests for the new features

Test plan

  • Open comment list with Shift+L
  • Navigate comments with j/k or arrow keys
  • Jump to comment location with Enter
  • Delete individual comments with d key
  • Use Shift+C and Shift+D in both main view and modal
  • Verify other shortcuts are disabled when modals are open
  • Close modal with Escape
  • All existing tests pass
  • New tests added for CommentsListModal and scope management

🤖 Generated with Claude Code

nodes.messageHeadline: fix: Fix issue where last comment is not output when closing window (…

nodes.bodyHTML:
Summary

Fixed a bug where the last comment was not displayed in stdout when closing the browser window with multiple comments.

Bug Details

Symptom

When posting multiple comments and then closing the window, the last comment was missing from the terminal output.

Root Cause

The original implementation had two issues:

  1. Unnecessary comment syncing: The useEffect cleanup function was sending old comment states to the server every time comments changed
  2. Server shutdown timing: The server was shutting down before the beforeunload event's sendBeacon request could be processed
// Original problematic code
useEffect(() => {
  const sendCommentsBeforeUnload = () => {
    // This function captures 'comments' at the time of creation (closure)
    if (comments.length > 0) {
      navigator.sendBeacon('/api/comments', { comments });
    }
  };
  
  window.addEventListener('beforeunload', sendCommentsBeforeUnload);
  
  return () => {
    window.removeEventListener('beforeunload', sendCommentsBeforeUnload);
    sendCommentsBeforeUnload(); // ⚠️ Sends old 'comments' state\!
  };
}, [comments]); // Re-runs every time comments change

Example Timeline

  1. Add comment 1:

    • comments changes from [] to ['comment 1']
    • Cleanup runs with comments = [] → sends empty array to server
    • New listener created with comments = ['comment 1']

  2. Add comment 2:

    • comments changes to ['comment 1', 'comment 2']
    • Cleanup runs with comments = ['comment 1'] → sends to server (missing comment 2)
    • New listener created with comments = ['comment 1', 'comment 2']
    • Server now has ['comment 1'] stored

  3. Close window:

    • beforeunload event fires → sends ['comment 1', 'comment 2'] via sendBeacon
    • SSE connection closes → server immediately exits
    • Problem: Server exits before processing the sendBeacon request
    • Server outputs the last received data: ['comment 1'] (missing comment 2)

Solution

  1. Changed to sync comments on every update - ensures server always has the latest comments:
// New implementation
useEffect(() => {
  // Sync comments whenever they change
  if (comments.length > 0) {
    fetch('/api/comments', {
      method: 'POST',
      headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
      body: JSON.stringify({ comments }),
    });
  }

  // Also handle page unload as fallback
  const sendCommentsBeforeUnload = () => {
    if (comments.length > 0) {
      navigator.sendBeacon('/api/comments', data);
    }
  };

  window.addEventListener('beforeunload', sendCommentsBeforeUnload);

  return () => {
    window.removeEventListener('beforeunload', sendCommentsBeforeUnload);
  };
}, [comments]);
  1. Added server-side delay - gives time for sendBeacon requests to be processed:
req.on('close', () => {
  clearInterval(heartbeatInterval);
  // Add a small delay to ensure any pending sendBeacon requests are processed
  setTimeout(() => {
    console.log('Client disconnected, shutting down server...');
    outputFinalComments();
    process.exit(0);
  }, 100);
});

Implementation Notes

  • The 100ms server-side delay is crucial - without it, the sendBeacon request doesn't get processed before the server exits
  • This approach maintains the original behavior of syncing comments but ensures it's always the latest state
  • The beforeunload handler remains as a fallback for reliability

Alternative Approach

If the intention is to send comments only once at the end, we could use useRef to maintain a reference to the latest comments:

const commentsRef = useRef(comments);
useEffect(() => {
  commentsRef.current = comments;
}, [comments]);

useEffect(() => {
  // Set up listener only once
  const sendComments = () => {
    navigator.sendBeacon('/api/comments', { comments: commentsRef.current });
  };
  window.addEventListener('beforeunload', sendComments);
  // ...
}, []); // Empty dependency array

However, this would still require the server-side delay for sendBeacon processing.

Test Plan

  • Add multiple comments and verify all are displayed when closing the window
  • Test with Ctrl+C termination
  • Verify existing /api/comments-output endpoint still works

🤖 Generated with Claude Code

nodes.bodyText: @haya14busa Thank you!!

nodes.title: fix: Fix issue where last comment is not output when closing window
nodes.titleHTML: fix: Fix issue where last comment is not output when closing window

nodes.messageHeadline: feat: Add Gerrit-style word highlighting to diff viewer (#62)

nodes.body: ## Summary - Implemented Gerrit-style word highlighting feature for the diff viewer - When hovering over a word, all occurrences of that word are highlighted throughout the visible diff - Helps track variable usage and identify patterns in code reviews ## Implementation Details - Created `WordHighlightContext` for global state management - Extended `PrismSyntaxHighlighter` with `EnhancedPrismSyntaxHighlighter` to preserve syntax highlighting - Added 200ms hover delay to avoid accidental highlights - Case-insensitive word matching - Supports both light and dark themes - Handles XML/HTML tokens that contain multiple words ## Test Plan - [x] Unit tests for word detection logic - [x] Unit tests for WordHighlightContext - [x] Unit tests for EnhancedPrismSyntaxHighlighter - [x] Manual testing in both light and dark modes - [x] Verified no regression in existing syntax highlighting - [x] Tested with various file types (JS, TS, HTML, etc.) - [x] Verified memory leak prevention with proper cleanup ## Screenshots The implementation matches Gerrit's behavior with a yellow highlight on hover. 🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)
nodes.bodyHTML:
Summary

  • Implemented Gerrit-style word highlighting feature for the diff viewer
  • When hovering over a word, all occurrences of that word are highlighted throughout the visible diff
  • Helps track variable usage and identify patterns in code reviews

Implementation Details

  • Created WordHighlightContext for global state management
  • Extended PrismSyntaxHighlighter with EnhancedPrismSyntaxHighlighter to preserve syntax highlighting
  • Added 200ms hover delay to avoid accidental highlights
  • Case-insensitive word matching
  • Supports both light and dark themes
  • Handles XML/HTML tokens that contain multiple words

Test Plan

  • Unit tests for word detection logic
  • Unit tests for WordHighlightContext
  • Unit tests for EnhancedPrismSyntaxHighlighter
  • Manual testing in both light and dark modes
  • Verified no regression in existing syntax highlighting
  • Tested with various file types (JS, TS, HTML, etc.)
  • Verified memory leak prevention with proper cleanup

Screenshots

The implementation matches Gerrit's behavior with a yellow highlight on hover.

🤖 Generated with Claude Code
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Implemented Gerrit-style word highlighting feature for the diff viewer
When hovering over a word, all occurrences of that word are highlighted throughout the visible diff
Helps track variable usage and identify patterns in code reviews

Implementation Details

Created WordHighlightContext for global state management
Extended PrismSyntaxHighlighter with EnhancedPrismSyntaxHighlighter to preserve syntax highlighting
Added 200ms hover delay to avoid accidental highlights
Case-insensitive word matching
Supports both light and dark themes
Handles XML/HTML tokens that contain multiple words

Test Plan

 Unit tests for word detection logic
 Unit tests for WordHighlightContext
 Unit tests for EnhancedPrismSyntaxHighlighter
 Manual testing in both light and dark modes
 Verified no regression in existing syntax highlighting
 Tested with various file types (JS, TS, HTML, etc.)
 Verified memory leak prevention with proper cleanup

Screenshots
The implementation matches Gerrit's behavior with a yellow highlight on hover.

🤖 Generated with Claude Code
@haya14busa Thank you!!

nodes.titleHTML: feat: Add Gerrit-style word highlighting to diff viewer

nodes.messageHeadline: feat: Add stdin support for reading unified diffs (#58)

nodes.body:
## Summary

This PR adds support for reading unified diffs from stdin, enabling powerful pipeline workflows with difit.

## Features

- **Automatic detection**: Detects piped input via `\!process.stdin.isTTY`
- **Explicit mode**: Use `-` argument to force reading from stdin
- **Full compatibility**: Reuses existing diff parsing logic for consistency
- **Flexible workflows**: Works with any tool that outputs unified diff format

## Usage Examples

```bash
# Basic usage - pipe git diff output
git diff | npx difit

# Explicit stdin mode
git diff | npx difit -

# Custom context lines
git diff -U10 | npx difit

# Compare against merge base
git diff --merge-base main feature | npx difit

# View diffs from other tools
diff -u file1.txt file2.txt | npx difit

# Review saved patches
cat changes.patch | npx difit
```

## Implementation Details

- Added `readStdin()` function to read from process.stdin
- Created `parseStdinDiff()` method that leverages existing `parseUnifiedDiff()`
- Extracted `countLinesFromChunks()` helper to avoid code duplication
- Added comprehensive test coverage in `git-diff.test.ts`
- Updated server to handle pre-parsed diff data from stdin

## Test Plan

- [x] Added 9 new test cases for stdin parsing functionality
- [x] Added unit test for `countLinesFromChunks` helper
- [x] All existing tests pass (209 passed)
- [x] Manual testing with various diff sources
- [x] ESLint and TypeScript checks pass

## Notes

- Syntax highlighting works as expected (language detection from filenames in diff)
- Comments work but use a generic storage key since there's no git commit hash
- Image diffs cannot be displayed (no access to actual file content)

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>
nodes.bodyHTML:
Summary

This PR adds support for reading unified diffs from stdin, enabling powerful pipeline workflows with difit.

Features

  • Automatic detection: Detects piped input via \!process.stdin.isTTY
  • Explicit mode: Use - argument to force reading from stdin
  • Full compatibility: Reuses existing diff parsing logic for consistency
  • Flexible workflows: Works with any tool that outputs unified diff format

Usage Examples

# Basic usage - pipe git diff output
git diff | npx difit

# Explicit stdin mode
git diff | npx difit -

# Custom context lines
git diff -U10 | npx difit

# Compare against merge base

# View diffs from other tools

# Review saved patches

  • Created parseStdinDiff() method that leverages existing parseUnifiedDiff()

nodes.messageHeadline: fix: handle empty files in keyboard navigation (#60)

nodes.body:
## Summary
- Fixed keyboard navigation to properly handle empty files and chunks
- Prevents navigation from getting stuck when encountering files with no content
- Added comprehensive test coverage for empty file scenarios

## Problem
Keyboard navigation would break in rare cases when encountering:
- Empty files (files with no chunks)
- Files with empty chunks (chunks with no lines)

This can occur in edge cases such as:
- Files temporarily added with `git add -N` (intent to add) that are later deleted
- Certain diff scenarios where files exist but have no actual content changes
- Other rare cases where the diff parser produces empty chunks/lines

## Solution
Modified the `advancePosition` function in `navigationCore.ts` to:
- Continue advancing through empty files/chunks instead of returning invalid positions
- Properly wrap around when all files are empty (to prevent infinite loops)
- Skip to the next file with actual content when normal advancement fails

## Test plan
- [x] Added comprehensive tests for empty file scenarios
- [x] All existing tests pass
- [x] Linting passes
- [x] Manually tested keyboard navigation with empty files

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

nodes.messageHeadline: Add Hot Reload Feature with File Watching and Manual Refresh (#61)

nodes.body:
## Summary

Added a hot reload feature that automatically detects repository changes and provides a GitHub-style manual reload button. This implementation uses high-performance file watching with mode-aware monitoring strategies.

### difit --watch

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6a761f19-b1ba-4ee7-baa8-55d3fa3eb9b5

### difit . --watch

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/70d1351d-e2e4-4baf-80a4-ada9345b0fb8

## Key Features

- **Automatic Change Detection**: Monitors file changes and commits based on diff mode
- **GitHub-style Reload Button**: Orange-colored reload button that appears when changes are detected
- **Smart Mode-aware Watching**: Different monitoring strategies for each diff mode (DEFAULT, WORKING, STAGED, DOT)
- **Gitignore Support**: Respects .gitignore patterns when watching working directory
- **Real-time Communication**: Server-Sent Events (SSE) for instant change notifications
- **Comprehensive Testing**: 265 test cases covering all components and edge cases

## Usage

Enable file watching by adding the `--watch` flag to any difit command:

```bash
# Watch for new commits when viewing HEAD diff
difit --watch

# Watch for file changes when viewing working directory
difit . --watch

# Watch for staging changes
difit working --watch

# Watch for uncommitted changes (files + commits)
difit HEAD main --watch
```

When changes are detected, an orange "Reload" button appears next to the "Ignore Whitespace" toggle. Click it to refresh the diff view with the latest changes.

**Note**: The `--watch` flag is currently supported only in GUI mode. TUI support will be added in future releases.

## Design Decisions

- **Manual Reload vs Auto-reload**: Chose manual reload button over automatic refresh to prevent disrupting the review experience when AI tools are running in the background
- **GUI-first Implementation**: Started with GUI support as it provides better user experience for the reload button. TUI support is planned for future releases

## Implementation Details

### Architecture Overview

```
┌─────────────────┐    SSE     ┌──────────────────┐    File Events    ┌─────────────────┐
│   React Client  │ ◄────────► │   Express Server │ ◄───────────────► │ @parcel/watcher │
│                 │            │                  │                   │                 │
│ - ReloadButton  │            │ - FileWatcher    │                   │ - .git/HEAD     │
│ - useFileWatch  │            │ - SSE Endpoint   │                   │ - .git/index    │
│ - App.tsx       │            │ - Cache Manager  │                   │ - Working files │
└─────────────────┘            └──────────────────┘                   └─────────────────┘
```

### File Watching Strategy by Mode

- **DEFAULT Mode**: Watches `.git/HEAD` for new commits
- **WORKING Mode**: Watches working directory + staging area for file changes
- **STAGED Mode**: Watches `.git/index` for staging changes  
- **DOT Mode**: Watches working directory + commits for uncommitted changes
- **SPECIFIC Mode**: No watching (static commit comparison)

### Core Components

- **FileWatcherService**: High-performance file monitoring with @parcel/watcher
- **ReloadButton**: GitHub-style UI component with loading states
- **useFileWatch**: React hook for SSE communication and state management
- **Type System**: Comprehensive TypeScript definitions for watch events

## Changes Made

### New Files
- `src/types/watch.ts` - Shared type definitions for watch functionality
- `src/server/file-watcher.ts` - Core file watching service implementation
- `src/client/hooks/useFileWatch.ts` - React hook for file watch integration
- `src/client/components/ReloadButton.tsx` - GitHub-style reload button component

### Enhanced Files
- `src/server/server.ts` - Added SSE endpoint and cache invalidation
- `src/client/App.tsx` - Integrated reload button with keyboard navigation
- `src/cli/index.ts` - Added --watch flag and diff mode detection

### Test Coverage
- **29 ReloadButton tests**: Visibility, states, interactions, accessibility
- **13 useFileWatch tests**: SSE connection, reconnection, error handling
- **14 FileWatcherService tests**: Mode-specific watching, gitignore, debouncing
- **Additional CLI tests**: Watch functionality and mode detection

## Technical Highlights

- **Debounced Change Detection** (300ms): Prevents excessive reload notifications
- **Gitignore Integration**: Uses simple-git's checkIgnore for accurate file filtering
- **Auto-reconnection**: SSE connections automatically recover from network issues
- **Orange Color Scheme**: Matches GitHub's design language for reload buttons
- **Memory Efficient**: Proper cleanup of watchers and event listeners

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

Test Coverage

  • 29 ReloadButton tests: Visibility, states, interactions, accessibility

  • Additional CLI tests: Watch functionality and mode detection

  • Orange Color Scheme: Matches GitHub's design language for reload buttons
  • Memory Efficient: Proper cleanup of watchers and event listeners

nodes.messageHeadline: feat: Add support for @ symbol as Git HEAD alias (#57)

nodes.body:
## Summary
- Add support for `@` symbol as a Git HEAD alias in difit
- Allow `@` with parent/ancestor references like `@^`, `@~3`, etc.
- Fix validation that was explicitly rejecting `@` despite it being a valid Git reference

## Changes
- Updated `validateCommitish` function to recognize `@` patterns with regex `/^@(~\d+|\^\d*)*$/`
- Removed explicit rejection of `@` from `isValidBranchName` function
- Added comprehensive tests for `@` symbol usage
- Updated README with `@` usage examples

## Test plan
- [x] Added new test cases for `@`, `@^`, `@~1`, `@~2^1` etc.
- [x] All existing tests pass
- [x] Manually verified `git log -1 @` and `git log -1 @~3` work correctly
- [x] Build and lint checks pass

## Why this matters
Git has supported `@` as an alias for HEAD since version 1.8.5. This is a common shorthand that many Git users expect to work. The previous validation was unnecessarily restrictive.

Example usage:
```bash
npx difit @          # Same as npx difit HEAD
npx difit @ main     # Compare HEAD with main
npx difit @^ @~3     # Compare previous commit with 3 commits ago
```

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

npx difit @ main     # Compare HEAD with main

nodes.messageHeadline: chore: release v2.0.11
feat: Add Gerrit-style keyboard navigation (#54)

nodes.body: ## Summary This PR introduces comprehensive Gerrit-style keyboard navigation to difit, enabling users to efficiently navigate through diffs using keyboard shortcuts. The implementation includes visual cursor highlighting, smart scrolling, and a help modal. ## Key Features ### 🎯 Navigation Commands - **Line Navigation**: `j`/`k` or `↓`/`↑` - Navigate between diff lines - **File Navigation**: `]`/`[` - Jump between files - **Chunk Navigation**: `n`/`p` - Navigate between change chunks (added/deleted lines) - **Comment Navigation**: `N`/`P` (Shift+n/p) - Jump between comments - **Side Navigation**: `h`/`l` or `←`/`→` - Switch between left/right sides (side-by-side mode only) ### 🔧 Actions - **Review Toggle**: `r` - Mark file as reviewed/unreviewed (with auto-scroll to file header) - **Add Comment**: `c` - Create comment at current line (not on deleted lines) - **Copy Comments**: `Shift+C` - Copy all comments prompt to clipboard - **Center View**: `.` - Move cursor to center of viewport - **Help**: `?` - Toggle keyboard shortcuts help modal ### 🎨 Visual Improvements - Visual cursor highlighting with blue outline (#4d7adb) - Responsive 2-column help modal layout on larger screens (≥1024px) - Smart scrolling that positions focused elements at 1/3 from top - Skip collapsed/reviewed files during navigation ### 🔨 Technical Improvements - Modular architecture with separate files for navigation logic - Comprehensive test coverage (1000+ lines of tests) - Filter-based navigation system for extensibility - Proper handling of side-by-side vs inline modes - Mouse click integration to set cursor position ## Implementation Details The keyboard navigation is implemented using: - A custom React hook (`useKeyboardNavigation`) that manages cursor state - Filter-based navigation system that makes it easy to define navigation targets - Smart scrolling behavior inspired by Gerrit's implementation - Proper handling of edge cases (deleted lines, paired add/delete lines, etc.) ## Test plan - [x] All existing tests pass - [x] Added comprehensive test suite for keyboard navigation (24 test cases) - [x] Pre-commit hooks pass (format, typecheck, test, lint) - [x] Manual testing of all keyboard shortcuts - [x] Manual testing in both side-by-side and inline modes - [x] Manual testing of help modal responsiveness - [ ] Manual testing with large diffs 🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)
nodes.bodyHTML:
Summary

This PR introduces comprehensive Gerrit-style keyboard navigation to difit, enabling users to efficiently navigate through diffs using keyboard shortcuts. The implementation includes visual cursor highlighting, smart scrolling, and a help modal.

Key Features

🎯 Navigation Commands

  • Line Navigation: j/k or ↓/↑ - Navigate between diff lines
  • File Navigation: ]/[ - Jump between files
  • Chunk Navigation: n/p - Navigate between change chunks (added/deleted lines)
  • Comment Navigation: N/P (Shift+n/p) - Jump between comments
  • Side Navigation: h/l or ←/→ - Switch between left/right sides (side-by-side mode only)

🔧 Actions

  • Review Toggle: r - Mark file as reviewed/unreviewed (with auto-scroll to file header)
  • Add Comment: c - Create comment at current line (not on deleted lines)
  • Copy Comments: Shift+C - Copy all comments prompt to clipboard
  • Center View: . - Move cursor to center of viewport
  • Help: ? - Toggle keyboard shortcuts help modal

🎨 Visual Improvements

  • Visual cursor highlighting with blue outline (#4d7adb)
  • Responsive 2-column help modal layout on larger screens (≥1024px)
  • Smart scrolling that positions focused elements at 1/3 from top
  • Skip collapsed/reviewed files during navigation

🔨 Technical Improvements

  • Modular architecture with separate files for navigation logic
  • Comprehensive test coverage (1000+ lines of tests)
  • Filter-based navigation system for extensibility
  • Proper handling of side-by-side vs inline modes
  • Mouse click integration to set cursor position

Implementation Details

The keyboard navigation is implemented using:

  • A custom React hook (useKeyboardNavigation) that manages cursor state
  • Filter-based navigation system that makes it easy to define navigation targets
  • Smart scrolling behavior inspired by Gerrit's implementation
  • Proper handling of edge cases (deleted lines, paired add/delete lines, etc.)

Test plan

  • All existing tests pass
  • Added comprehensive test suite for keyboard navigation (24 test cases)
  • Pre-commit hooks pass (format, typecheck, test, lint)
  • Manual testing of all keyboard shortcuts
  • Manual testing in both side-by-side and inline modes
  • Manual testing of help modal responsiveness
  • Manual testing with large diffs

🤖 Generated with Claude Code
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR introduces comprehensive Gerrit-style keyboard navigation to difit, enabling users to efficiently navigate through diffs using keyboard shortcuts. The implementation includes visual cursor highlighting, smart scrolling, and a help modal.

Key Features
🎯 Navigation Commands

Line Navigation: j/k or ↓/↑ - Navigate between diff lines
File Navigation: ]/[ - Jump between files
Chunk Navigation: n/p - Navigate between change chunks (added/deleted lines)
Comment Navigation: N/P (Shift+n/p) - Jump between comments
Side Navigation: h/l or ←/→ - Switch between left/right sides (side-by-side mode only)

🔧 Actions

Review Toggle: r - Mark file as reviewed/unreviewed (with auto-scroll to file header)
Add Comment: c - Create comment at current line (not on deleted lines)
Copy Comments: Shift+C - Copy all comments prompt to clipboard
Center View: . - Move cursor to center of viewport
Help: ? - Toggle keyboard shortcuts help modal

🎨 Visual Improvements

Visual cursor highlighting with blue outline (#4d7adb)
Responsive 2-column help modal layout on larger screens (≥1024px)
Smart scrolling that positions focused elements at 1/3 from top
Skip collapsed/reviewed files during navigation

🔨 Technical Improvements

Modular architecture with separate files for navigation logic
Comprehensive test coverage (1000+ lines of tests)
Filter-based navigation system for extensibility
Proper handling of side-by-side vs inline modes
Mouse click integration to set cursor position

Implementation Details
The keyboard navigation is implemented using:

A custom React hook (useKeyboardNavigation) that manages cursor state
Filter-based navigation system that makes it easy to define navigation targets
Smart scrolling behavior inspired by Gerrit's implementation
Proper handling of edge cases (deleted lines, paired add/delete lines, etc.)

Test plan

 All existing tests pass
 Added comprehensive test suite for keyboard navigation (24 test cases)
 Pre-commit hooks pass (format, typecheck, test, lint)
 Manual testing of all keyboard shortcuts
 Manual testing in both side-by-side and inline modes
 Manual testing of help modal responsiveness
 Manual testing with large diffs

🤖 Generated with Claude Code

You can check out Gerrit's keyboard shortcuts with Go's review site (Gerrit) for example.
https://go-review.googlesource.com/c/go/+/688095
@haya14busa  Thank you! Cool!

nodes.title: feat: Add Gerrit-style keyboard navigation
